title: Monday, 12th September, 2016
bodyHTML:

..... Just me today, incidentally. And we'll be going a bit slow, as I've been struggling to find much to say.

11:10 am

BE

BE

Why? Well, because the S&P finished the day down 2.5%, down 1.4% from the European close.

11:11 am
BE

We can talk about interest rate jitters and stuff, but it's all Friday's story really.

BE

As well as how utterly, tediously dull it's been through summer.

BE

Here's the FTSE in dollars (which I'm increasingly convinced is the only sensible way to view it).

11:12 am
BE

BE

That line post the Brexit vote is almost spookily straight .............. It's been hella dull recently.

BE

Want a "death of volatility" piece from Deutsche? Course you don't, yet here one comes.

11:14 am
BE

S&P realized volatility has been extremely low the last 6 weeks, but we think this is the quiet before the storm. We see five catalysts to increased volatility this autumn: 1) analyst btm-up 2017E S&P EPS cuts during 3Q reporting, 2) no Fed hike in Sept with no clear explanation as to when, 3) macro data that suggests an "L shaped" capex recovery, 4) US election and policy uncertainty, 5) PEs fully dependent on low bond yields at bond substitutes and also at cyclicals, like Energy & Industrials, when low yields should be a greater benefit to PEs at non-cyclical growth sector like Tech & Health Care. Near-term we favor Utilities & Telecom over Financials. We favor lower PE mega-caps.

BE

STD of annualized daily S&P price moves has been 6% since August started. The lowest 30 day+ vol since Aug-Sep of 1995 and versus a 14% monthly average since 1960. Only 1964, 1993 & 1995 had vol at such low levels for more than a few months and these are the only three years the S&P didn’t suffer a 5%+ dip from its one year high. Dips of 5%+ usually occur twice a year. 2016 had 2 dips already and we expect another soon. Unlike the straight-up halcyon years above, 2016 is later in the cycle with 0% S&P EPS growth vs. strong double-digit growth in those years. Post recession normalizing Fed hikes were behind by 1964 & 1995. 1964 was an election year, but LBJ was an in place successor. Current volatility is a poor indicator of future risk. It has a long history of mean reversion and is prone to sudden spikes. Our fundamental assessment of S&P risk puts it lower than 2008-2012, but not below long-term history. We take concern with this very low vol amidst low volume and high PEs. One of our favorite risk sentiment indicators, which we use in a contrarian fashion, the PE/VIX ratio signals a very complacent market.

BE

Our profit indicator suggests 3Q S&P EPS had little or no growth from 2Q. We expect 3Q S&P EPS to be near $30 or down 1% y/y. Unless oil climbs strongly, quarterly S&P EPS is likely $30-31 through 1H17. We expect 3Q reporting to lower btm-up 2017 EPS most at Financials, Staples, Con Disc and Industrials. The general expectation for 2017 S&P EPS will fall from $130 to $125-130.

11:14 am
BE

The fwd PE on our 2017E EPS for Tech & HC is 17.1 & 15.2 vs. 28.7 & 17.3 for Energy & Industrials. Our EPS assumes oil prices avg near $55/bbl in 2017. The 30yr avg trailing PE for Tech & HC are both about 20 ex recessions and 1999 and about 17.5 for Energy & Industrials on same basis. Lower rates support higher steady-state PEs vs history, but Rf rates are a greater proportion of the cost of equity for low beta stocks and thus should benefit low beta stock PEs more. It’s Health Care and parts of Tech that have best chance of generating economic profit growth, which is also worth more amidst low rates. Tech & HC have the strongest balance sheets and can borrow cheaply vs. their EPS yields.

BE

We believe the market is wrongly priced by sector for a sustained acceleration in trend US growth led by industrial activity or perhaps a sharp decline in the dollar that boosts commodities and increase US share of global capex. We see neither scenario as likely, thus a relative revaluation of sectors is needed soon.

BE

More on the theme via David: http://ftalphavill...-is-low-not-cheap/

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,829, up 9.5 (+0.20%), High: 4,845, Low: 4,777, Volume: 514.79k
AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,829, up 9.5 (+0.20%), High: 4,845, Low: 4,777, Volume: 514.79k

Jefferies is excited about the Mystic trial.

BE

A Phase III durvalumab-tremelimumab trial for non-small cell lung cancer.

BE

I've been through the whole note and it's a bit vague on the specific reasons for optimism, but the general thesis is that AstraZeneca has a one-year lead on BMS.

11:19 am
BE

Incidentally, I encourage you to have a poke around AstraZeneca's website.

BE

It's been totally redesigned since the Pfizer tilt, and its really good.

BE

Here's the oncology section, which is full of video explainers and interactive timelines https://www.astraz...reas/oncology.html

11:21 am
BE

I guess AZN hired a load of good PR people for the Pfizer defence, who then found they didn't have anything to do. The benefit is a very shiny website.

BE

Here's Jefferies

BE

We have upgraded AstraZeneca shares to Buy (from Hold) as we believe that the shares and consensus estimates fail to reflect the significant valuation upside we see on the potential positive outcome of the MYSTIC study in Q1’17. Our base case valuation set at a 65% probability for MYSTIC being successful drives a DCF valuation of 5,774p, whilst actual success would raise it by c936p to 6,710p, some 39% above where the shares currently trade. Alternatively, complete failure of the durva/ treme program in NSCLC would trigger c1,424p downside to our DCF to 4,350p per share, 10% lower than where the shares currently trade.

11:22 am
BE

With MYSTIC not expected by us to read out before February 2017, it may feel a little early to upgrade the shares now, given some of the recent outperformance. However, much of the recent bid speculation has fallen out of the stock price and the residual outperformance from the Brexit decision should stay within the stock price as long as the US$:£ rate holds at around current levels. Outside of these factors, there are now a limited number of catalysts both for AstraZeneca and for Immuno-Oncology within the NSCLC setting and we believe that investors should work to be positioned in the shares by Q4’16 ahead of the MYSTIC study read out.

BE

In summary, we believe that the failure of Bristol-Myers’ CheckMate-026 study has left open a greater than expected opportunity for combination Immuno-Oncology treatment in NSCLC and that AstraZeneca is best positioned amongst its peers to capitalize on it.

BE

After updating our NSCLC model as well as doing further work to reassure ourselves on MYSTIC’s probability of success, we have raised our EPS estimates up to 11% above consensus and our PT to 5,800p. We have also raised our rating to Buy, from Hold and see AstraZeneca shares as the best way for investors to get exposure to the Immuno-Oncology market opportunity within Large Cap Pharma.

11:28 am
BE

Results of SOLO2, a trial on treating relapses, due soon.

BE

• Bottom line: Ahead of the 2H:16 data readout for Lynparza’s (olaparib)
SOLO2 trial in the 2L maintenance setting for ovarian cancer, we spoke
with Dr. Susan Galbraith, head of AZN’s oncology innovative medicines
unit on the drug’s potential and the PARP inhibitor landscape in general.
While we continue to expect TSRO’s (OP) niraparib to gain the largest
share of the ovarian cancer market due to the strong efficacy seen
across a broader population in the NOVA trial, the breadth of AZN’s DNA
damage response (DDR) portfolio clearly establishes it as a leader in
the field. Overall, this reinforces our view of the broad appeal of PARP
inhibitors to leading oncology players. The PARP class also includes PFE
(MP)/MDVN's (MP) talazoparib, CLVS's (NR) rucaparib, ABBV's (NR)
veliparib, and BGNE's (NR) BGB-290. We reiterate our MP rating and
$35/ADR price target for AZN.

Primark sales continue to deteriorate.

11:32 am

Why? Dunno. That's the great mystery.

BE

There's also a scale argument.

11:34 am
BE

As we were (or rather, as Morgan Stanley was) saying back in June .....

BE

With one in every seven items of clothing in the UK now purchased in Primark, and with sales volumes per square foot already four times those of peers, the deterioration in recent years looks to be at least partly structural.

BE

https://www.ft.com...-a780-b48ed7b6126f

11:05 am
BE

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily wander around the financial ..... vista?

BE

Primark sales are up 9% at constant currency, in line with increased selling
space, but this includes 2% from a 53rd trading week so LFL down 2%. We think that
means 4Q LFL sales were down 3% (1H -1%, 3Q – 2.5%). The UK clothing market saw
some recovery in July (1% growth yoy according to the ONS) after a difficult spring, but
hot weather presented challenges in August. Weather can be blamed for some of the 4Q
performance but with ASOS and Boohoo both posting strong double-digit sales, the lack
of online at Primark raises questions about structural weakness. The company is also
flagging up lower margins in Primark next year due to weaker sterling’s effect on input
costs.

BE

This is via SocGen

11:36 am
BE

Sugar World raw sugar prices have risen by 30% since April, reflecting lower anticipated
output. Although the company confirmed AB Sugar revenue and profit “will be ahead of
last year”, it also stated that British Sugar will not benefit until FY17 due to forward
contracts. The company has sold it Chinese cane sugar business.
Share price view We reduced our TP in July despite higher forecast sugar profits to
reflect the derating of the UK non-food retail sector. The share price has recovered
strongly since the 3Q results announcement and is close to where it was this time last
year. Although the overall results are no surprise, there may be some disappointment on
Primark’s LFL sales which have progressively declined this year.

BE

And Jefferies .............

BE

(@Bluesky21: to be clear, that MOST comment's from months ago.)

11:37 am
BE

Primark dynamics below expectations on a number of fronts. First of all, sales
momentum has failed to improve in the latter stages of the year, with ex fx (and ex 53rd
week) sales growth of 7% for FY (in line with the first 40 weeks of 15/16). LFL of -2% for
FY confirms a weakening trend in H2 (after c.-1% in H1). Secondly, margin commentary
(FY to be close to the 11.9% seen in H1, despite Q3 having continued at 11.9%) also looks
softer than hoped for. And lastly, space expansion of 1.2m sqft for the past year is well below the 1.5m sqft target, while the 1.3m sqft ambition set for the year ahead is also below our estimates.

BE

Stock vulnerable at close to peak valuation as we estimate that (at the current spot
price of slightly above 3000p and the group on c.25x) Primark is currently priced in at greater than 32x cal 2017 earnings. With the retail chain unlikely to see underlying sales growth reaccelerate to double-digit in the year ahead (and margins impacted by sourcing pressures), this may start looking on the generous side (vs ITX on 28x, for instance).

BE

Here's the key chart.

11:38 am
BE

BE

And Morgan Stanley from today. Geoff Ruddell's the analyst of course.

BE

- Probably the most important piece of 'new news' this morning is that ABF has
slightly raised its EPS guidance for the year. Earlier in the year management had
been predicting a 'modest' decline in adjusted EPS for FY 2015/16. Back in July
management said it was no longer expecting EPS to decline. Today the guidance
was raised further, with EPS now expected to be "marginally ahead" of last year,
with FY H2 operating profits "ahead of our expectation". Although we suspect the
upgrade will not be material, the positive momentum should be taken well, we
think.
- With Retail accounting for 70+% of the group's value in most analysts' sum of
the parts, the divisional commentary on Primark is likely to attract the most
attention today. Stripping out the 2% benefit from the 53rd week, total sales for
the year were up 9% on a constant currency basis. This compares with 7% at the
end of FY Q3, suggesting improved momentum in FYQ4. Nevertheless, LfLs for
the full year were -2%. This is the first time the company has reported a negative
full year LfL since the company began disclosing LfLs in the early noughties.
Primark opened three additional stores in the US during the quarter and today's
update suggests that management is "encouraged" by their performance. The
statement warns that adverse FX is likely to hit Primark margins next year,
though this shouldn’t come as a surprise.

11:40 am
BE

- The other division likely to get some attention today is Sugar, with the company
announcing this morning that it has agreed to sell its cane sugar business in
China to a consortium led by Nanning Sugar. There had been some speculation
that a sale was being considered, but this is nevertheless 'new news'. The
statement does not give details of the consideration ABF will receive.
- We have yet to speak to management this morning, but we suspect that the
"modest" EPS growth referred to in today's statement is unlikely to lead to
material upgrades today (consensus was already looking for c2% EPS growth for
the year). According to Bloomberg, consensus is currently looking for FY 2015/16
Pre Tax Profits of £1053m, (1.038p of EPS).
- Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, ABF is
trading on 25.7x Calendarised 2017 earnings, 13.8x EBITDA, with a Dividend Yield
of 1.3%. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 13.7x, 8.4x and
3.5% respectively (Inditex is trading on 28.3x, 16.2x and 2.3%).

BE

So the picture here is that they're not bad figures, at least against expectations. But it was a bad day to stick them out, particularly when your underpants business is at an implied PE nudging into the 40s.

undefined
11:42 am
BE

Nothing really in the weekend press to pick up on.

BE

Well. Cobham, I guess.

BE

http://www.thetime...n-cobham-z3ljm0lqq

11:43 am
BE

Very .............. well, it's a very carefully written story, I guess.

Cobham PLC (COB:LSE): Last: 167.70, down 1.4 (-0.83%), High: 171.30, Low: 167.10, Volume: 1.20m
BE

Doesn't mention bidders about which Whitehall might be spooked about.

11:45 am
BE

Doesn't really explain why Cobham getting bought should spook Whitehall. Would it matter if it were owned by KKR or Carlyle, the PE companies that get cursory references in the story?

BE

Doesn't really go into whether merging Cobham with Meggitt would be a good or a bad thing, or explain what power Whitehall might have to force such a move.

BE

We know Meggitt and Cobham have talked in the past. The last talks resulted in Meggitt buying Cobham's aerospace design business in August.

11:48 am
BE

Also, Cobham's between CEOs.

BE

And its shares have gone from 136p to 160-ish in the past three months, so it's a wee bit tricky to make the "distressed share price attracting predators" argument too.

BE

Still ... I guess there must be a reason why the Sunday Times put the placeholder down. It's not a reason we've heard though.

11:50 am
undefined
BE

Back to sellside?

Pets at Home Group PLC (PETS:LSE): Last: 247.50, up 2 (+0.81%), High: 248.20, Low: 240.40, Volume: 126.33k
11:51 am
BE

Citi likes.

BE

We initiate with a Buy given our expectation of the medium term margin upside opportunity and cash returns. Over the next 10 years we believe the vet business could generate an incremental £40m EBITDA on a FY16 Group EBITDA base of £125m and account for greater than 35% of group EBITDA (est c.18% today), and £225m of cash could be returned in dividends over the next 3 years.

BE

We've talked in the past about Pets' vets business, right? It's entirely anecdotal, of course, but my impression of vets is that they're fairly small owner-operator practices that don't tend to fall into natural partnerships with ringworm tablet salesmen.

11:53 am
BE

Pets at Home is the lead UK specialist pet retailer, with 427 stores (target 500) and 20% market share of the total pet care merchandise market. In addition it has a growing presence in services, with 388 veterinary practices (target 700), a higher margin business. It generates Group EBITDA margins of 16% and a capitalized ROIC of c.20%.

BE

Our investment thesis is structured on: 1) Merchandise continuing to drive topline through store growth and LFL, although headwinds (FX, investments) will limit EBITDA growth; 2) services as the key driver of EBITDA growth through expansion and maturity; 3) online competition a concern but perhaps not as disruptive as may be expected; 4) against an uncertain UK demand outlook Pet Care looks more resilient; and 5) the company will soon start to return excess cash to shareholders.

BE

This assumes Merchandise sales +4% CAGR (LFL +1.3%; space +2.6%) with services +20%. We expect group margin dilution in FY17 and FY18 (investments; cost headwinds) but recovery in FY19 as underlying trends come through.

11:53 am
BE

Given different growth and returns profiles across the business our target price is SOTP driven (13x FY18E EV/EBIT on merchandise; 18x on services). This is supported by a DCF that assumes terminal EBITDA margin of c.19% vs. 16% today. A premium valuation to peers is justified, in our view, by high ROIC, longer-term services opportunity, cash returns and relative defensiveness.

BE

............ though I know this thing has its fans, to which I guess we can add Citi.

undefined
11:55 am
BE

(@Rigby: sure, though increasing from what kind of base? It still looks like a very fragmented market to me. It's also structurally fragmented, I'd argue, just as dry-cleaning is.)

BE

There's also Ian Gordon at Investec selling RBS.

BE

What’s the point? - Sell

11:56 am
BE

I can emphathise.

BE

After RBS’ participation in the recent sector rally, we downgrade to Sell (from Hold). Minor forecast changes take our TP to 200p (from 205p). Barclays (Hold) is our preferred “recovery play” while Lloyds (Buy) is our preferred FTSE100 bank. However, we continue to see far greater upside within the UK “challenger bank” sub-sector; we highlight OneSavings (Buy), Shawbrook (Buy) and Virgin Money (Buy), while we think Aldermore (Buy) is the most underappreciated, undervalued story of all. In this context, why own RBS?

BE

RBS trades on 0.7x 2017e tNAV despite the fact that we expect it to remain loss-making with no dividend through 2016e and 2017e. We see its path to recovery as distant and uncertain. We also make minor downgrades to reflect AT1/equity issuance and a £400m FX loss on a Preference Share redemption.
We model further conduct costs of £4.8bn through H2 2016-2018e over and above the £7.5bn of provisions held on balance sheet. We have low conviction as to whether this will ultimately prove to be the correct number! Our £2.5bn restructuring costs over the same period may yet see further “inflation” as RBS desperately tries to take out underlying costs as revenue pressures intensify.
We note the recent raft of encouraging UK economic data which (we think) goes a long way to putting the Brexit doom-mongers “back in their box”. As such, we expect to see quite significant upgrades to consensus forecasts for balance sheet growth elsewhere – especially among the challenger banks – but not for RBS. It actually achieved a very creditable pace of growth in its UK retail/corporate businesses in H1 2016, which we do expect to slow.
We remain enthusiastic on the opportunities presented for certain banks by the Term Finance Scheme. Rachel Reeves MP expressed her concern at last week’s Treasury Select Committee in relation to a potential boost to bank profitability arising from such cheap funding. Sadly, we do not believe she was referring to RBS which, with a loans:deposit ratio of 92%, appears unlikely to utilise TFS at all, and will, we think, suffer a disproportionate drag to NIM from “lower for longer” interest rates as the contribution from its hedge erodes.
We downgrade to Sell (from Hold).and cut our TP to 200p (from 205p).

11:58 am
BE

Oh, and while on banks .............

BE

Pressure on A HO. https://www.ft.com...-b60a-de4532d5ea35

BE

Two top 25 shareholders, who asked not to be named, said Lloyds clearly had no suitable successors internally and urgently needed to draw up a list of possible external candidates.

11:59 am
BE

How might the two top 25 shareholders know for sure that Lloyds hadn't drawn up a list of possible external candidates?

BE

Anyway, you all know the background to that one. So let's draw a veil.

undefined
12:01 pm
BE

Oh! Midday already!

BE

And there are still a few things we haven't mentioned.

BE

Crozier selling 500k of ITV this morning.

12:01 pm
ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 199.00, down 3.9 (-1.92%), High: 200.50, Low: 197.90, Volume: 3.77m
BE

Sunday Times had a ponder around the idea of Liberty buying ITV over the weekend: http://www.thetime...-century-vf0zm0glf

BE

The upshot of the thesis being that its price has fallen a bit.

12:04 pm
BE

We've also ignored SVG Capital

SVG Capital PLC (SVI:LSE): Last: 650.00, up 83.5 (+14.74%), High: 653.50, Low: 646.00, Volume: 14.75m
BE

HarbourVest bids 650p and gets Coller, 20% shareholder, onboard.

12:06 pm
BE

SVG says take no action. HarbourVest says take action, and sweeps the market for 8.5% early doors for the bid price giving it 51.2% including the irrevocables.

BE

Here comes Stifel ............

BE

Whilst HarbourVest says its offer is a 2.4% discount to SVG’s historical NAV, we estimate it could be a c.10% discount to 31/07/16 NAV. However, we think a counter offer is unlikely given the complexity of bids and the 51.2% support for HarbourVest following the market purchase of 8.5% today. The offer highlights ‘value’ in the sector.

12:07 pm
BE

Stifel view: The last time there was a sizeable bid in the listed private equity
sector, it was also structured as a final offer and this probably scuppered the
transaction. This was 3i Group’s bid for Electra back in 1999. On that
occasion, the offer appeared a bit low and shareholders rejected it. Whilst we
welcome today’s action to take advantage of the high discounts we have seen
in the listed private equity sector, we are surprised by the timing given that the
offer is based on the last NAV of 666p at 30/04/16. A new NAV to 31/07/16 is
due on 20 September and this will include the positive impact from sterling’s
devaluation. Taking into account our NAV estimate of 695p to 725p at
31/07/16, SVG may be being taken private at up to a c.10% discount.
HarbourVest says the offer takes into account recent forex moves and
short-term prospects. Many large shareholders agree, with 42.7% supportive.
This includes Coller who was a ‘saviour’ for SVG in 2008, but a subsequent
‘thorn in the side’ of management, together with Old Mutual, Aviva and L&G. In
addition, HarbourVest purchased 8.5% of shares in the market today, raising
support to 51.2%.
Given the offer gives shareholders cash in hand at a good uplift both to the
share price and also does partly at least reduce the ‘live’ discount on the
shares, we think it likely that the 50% of shareholders required to validly
accept the offer are likely to go along with it. Bids in the listed private equity
sector are notoriously difficult with a counter-offer unlikely.

BE

Sector read-across: We have long thought that a move to take a fund private
could be a catalyst for a re-rating of the 20% plus discount the sector has been
trading on and today’s news backs up our view that the listed private equity
sector offers significant value on a discount basis.
HarbourVest’s intentions: The Dover Street IX Fund has agreed to finance
capital contributions into HarbourVest Bidco, the entire cash consideration
payable to SVG shareholders. As at 09/09/16, the Dover Street IX Fund had
$4.1bn of capital commitments for investment. HarbourVest intends to change
the investment policy of SVG and cease making new investments.
HarbourVest does not expect to make any significant disposals of investments
but will instead continue to fund existing obligations from cash held in SVG.
The portfolio will mature in the medium term before moving into a period of
natural run-off in 10 to 12 years’ time as the underlying funds become fully
realised.
Recommendation: Following the price rise, we downgrade our
recommendation from Buy to Hold. Our fair valuation of 605p is raised to 650p.
Our NAV estimate is 695p to 725p at 31/07/16.

BE

(@chad_john: apologies. No. Head straight for the biryani.)

12:08 pm
undefined
BE

Okay, we're done I guess.

BE

Slightly subdued session, but Mondays are what they are.

12:09 pm
BE

Fingers crossed for tomorrow. We'll see you back here then. Afternoon all.

BE

As for today ............
